SubTopics: Organize and categorize important information; collaborate to validate or revise thinking; report relevant findings.
Content: A student is writing a report about clouds. Read the information from the source.

:ibox:Clouds are large collections of tiny water droplets or ice crystals. These droplets are so light that they float in the air. Heat from the sun causes the water in oceans, lakes, and rivers to evaporate, or become a gas. As the gas cools, it rises, and the water droplets begin to stick together. Millions of these tiny water droplets create the clouds we see in the sky.
Which subheading would BEST describe the information from this source?

A.Choice: How Clouds Form

B.Choice: Types of Clouds

C.Choice: How Clouds Move

D.Choice: Using Clouds to Predict Weather

SubTopics: Formulate questions to focus thinking on an idea to narrow and direct further inquiry.
Content: A student is planning to write a research report about whether video games are good for kids. Which question would BEST focus the research so that the student would find information to use in the report?

A.Choice: Which video games are most popular with young people?

B.Choice: What are some positive effects of playing video games?

C.Choice: When is a good time to introduce children to video games?

D.Choice: How do people begin a career creating video games?

SubTopics: Develop a plan of action for collecting relevant information from primary and secondary sources.
Content: A student has made a plan for a research report. Read the plan.

:box:Research Report Plan

Topic: space travel
Audience: teacher and classmates
Purpose: to inform
Research question: How has space travel changed since the first spacecraft landed on the moon?
The student found several sources. Which source would most likely have information that would be useful in the student's report?

A.Choice: a book titled The Space Mission Mystery

B.Choice: a book titled The History of Space Travel

C.Choice: a website that describes how to make model rockets for a classroom project

D.Choice: a newspaper article with the heading “Interesting Facts about the Moon and Stars”

SubTopics: Ask and answer inferential questions to analyze meaning beyond the text; refer to details and examples within a text to support inferences and conclusions.
Content: Which sentence from the passage supports the idea that Sam is still learning how to fish?

A.Choice: During these trips with Gran, Sam's attention would move from fishing to the beauty of his surroundings.

B.Choice: With a hoot of excitement, Sam watched as the tip of his pole bent sharply.

C.Choice: Sam was vaguely aware of Gran appearing next to him, calmly coaching him, whispering words of encouragement in his ear.

D.Choice: Sam knelt down and gently removed the fish from the line, taking care to hold it under the water as he admired the fish's size.

SubTopics: Determine the development of a theme within a text; summarize using key details.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS. FIRST, ANSWER PART A. THEN, ANSWER PART B.
What is the theme of the passage?

A.Choice: Spending time outside can help people forget their problems.

B.Choice: People should not worry about what others think.

C.Choice: Happy memories are an important part of life.

D.Choice: Mastering a new activity can take a long time.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer in part A?

A.Choice: Sam walked barefoot over the warm sand, enjoying the feel of the small grains under his feet.

B.Choice: It amazed him that, even when she was having a bad day, Gran could cast her line a good thirty feet farther than Sam could on his best day.

C.Choice: “No luck today, huh?” she asked.

D.Choice: With a quick wink to Gran, Sam smiled at the girl and replied, “Actually, it was one of the best days of my life!”

SubTopics: Explain how conflicts cause the characters to change or revise plans while moving toward resolution.
Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST shows that Sam has respect for both the fish and the battle of bringing it in?

A.Choice: Suddenly, a sharp tug on the line sent Sam stumbling.

B.Choice: “There it is!” Sam shouted breathlessly.

C.Choice: Sam took a moment to savor his victory.

D.Choice: “You put up a good fight,” Sam said softly.

SubTopics: Explain how the author's choice of words, illustrations, and conventions combine to create mood, contribute to meaning, and emphasize aspects of a character or setting.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.
:ibox:Wow, oh, wow, Sam thought to himself. This is bound to catch a whopper!
What do the sentences BEST reveal about Sam?

A.Choice: He feels hopeful about the day.

B.Choice: He has caught large fish before.

C.Choice: He thinks he will catch more fish than Gran.

D.Choice: He is better prepared for the day than Gran is.

SubTopics: Explain how the author's choice of words, illustrations, and conventions combine to create mood, contribute to meaning, and emphasize aspects of a character or setting.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.

:ibox:With a well-practiced toss, he sent the lure out into the deeper water beyond the waves and let it float back toward shore a bit. Sam waited a few seconds, giving the line time to sink, then started the slow, rhythmic process of reeling in the line.
What mood does the description in the sentences suggest?

A.Choice: a lonely mood

B.Choice: a peaceful mood

C.Choice: a humorous mood

D.Choice: a mysterious mood

SubTopics: Explain how the author's choice of words, illustrations, and conventions combine to create mood, contribute to meaning, and emphasize aspects of a character or setting.
Content: Which sentences from the passage BEST show the special relationship that Sam and Gran have? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: Giving Sam a friendly jab in the side with her arm, Gran continued down the shoreline with her fishing pole and tackle in hand.

B.Choice: As he reeled, Sam looked over to the spot Gran had claimed.

C.Choice: His grandmother often said that the fishing was secondary to the experience.

D.Choice: Hearing the call of the seagulls and the sounds of the surf, Sam thought he'd have to agree with his best friend, Gran.

E.Choice: He and Gran gathered their gear and headed up the dunes from the shore.

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fit together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:ibox:“I have a good feeling this morning, Sam,” Gran said as her blue eyes twinkled in the young sunlight.
How does this sentence fit into the overall structure of the passage?

A.Choice: It reveals the theme of the story.

B.Choice: It hints at the events that happen later in the story.

C.Choice: It hints at the major change of setting in the story.

D.Choice: It reveals the setting for the main events in the story.

SubTopics: Ask and answer inferential questions to analyze meaning beyond the text; refer to details and examples within a text to support inferences and conclusions.
Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the idea that students enjoy the GeoBee no matter how well they do in the contest?

A.Choice: The final two students in the 2009 National Geographic Bee waited patiently for their next question.

B.Choice: There, each student competes for the top geography prize in the nation.

C.Choice: Though he did not win, all his hard work and studying offered him a great chance to explore.

D.Choice: Yang admitted, though, that he hadn't known the answer to the final question right off the bat.

SubTopics: Ask and answer inferential questions to analyze meaning beyond the text; refer to details and examples within a text to support inferences and conclusions.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS. FIRST, ANSWER PART A. THEN, ANSWER PART B.
Based on the passage, what is a goal of the GeoBee?

A.Choice: to encourage students to learn about different parts of the world

B.Choice: to show students what it is like to take part in a game show

C.Choice: to help students from around the U.S. get to know one another

D.Choice: to give students a chance to take trips to different U.S. cities

Content: Which detail from the passage BEST supports the answer in part A?

A.Choice: The man who hosts the GeoBee also hosts a television show.

B.Choice: The national GeoBee takes place in Washington, D.C.

C.Choice: The GeoBee website offers study guides, quizzes, games, and maps.

D.Choice: GeoBee winners come from different states.

SubTopics: Summarize multi-paragraph texts using key details to support the central idea.
Content: Which information is a central idea that belongs in a summary of the passage?

A.Choice: GeoBee state winners get to travel with their teachers to the national contest.

B.Choice: GeoBee winners come from all different places and backgrounds.

C.Choice: One prize given in the 2009 GeoBee was a trip to South America.

D.Choice: David Beihl from South Carolina won the GeoBee in 1999.

SubTopics: Determine how the author uses words and phrases to shape and clarify meaning.
Content: Read these sentences from the passage.

:ibox:The National Geographic Bee—or “GeoBee,” as it is called—does not involve spelling. However, it is similar to Scripps in some ways. It encourages students to sharpen their memories and thinking skills.
What does the phrase “encourages students to sharpen” mainly reveal about the GeoBee?

A.Choice: The GeoBee has changed over time.

B.Choice: The GeoBee is very popular.

C.Choice: The GeoBee is difficult for students.

D.Choice: The GeoBee can be helpful to students.

SubTopics: Apply knowledge of text features to gain meaning; describe the relationship between these features and the text.
Content: What does the information inside the box BEST help readers to understand?

A.Choice: how students can prepare to answer the GeoBee questions

B.Choice: which questions students must answer in order to win the GeoBee

C.Choice: why students should use the GeoBee Challenge app

D.Choice: which questions Eric Yang got right in order to win the GeoBee

SubTopics: Apply knowledge of text structures to describe how structures contribute to meaning.
Content: How does the use of headings help the reader to understand the passage?

A.Choice: The headings state the central ideas of the passage.

B.Choice: The headings organize ideas from the passage.

C.Choice: The headings list in order the steps for taking part in the GeoBee.

D.Choice: The headings give solutions to some problems with the GeoBee.

SubTopics: Introduce a topic or text clearly, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure in which related ideas are grouped to support the writer's purpose.
Content: Read the draft of a student's essay.

:ibox:Zookeepers spend their days with animals. They learn what the animals like best and how to care for them. Many of the humans and animals form special relationships. The zookeepers are able to watch the animals grow and change over time. Sometimes, there is also an opportunity to feed and care for baby animals that are born in the zoo. What could be more fun and exciting than that?
Which sentence would provide the BEST introduction for the paragraph?

A.Choice: I hope to visit the zoo this summer with my family.

B.Choice: Animals such as bears and monkeys can be seen in many zoos.

C.Choice: I think that working at a zoo would be the best type of job.

D.Choice: There are hundreds of zoos in cities around the world.

SubTopics: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, and editing building on personal ideas and the ideas of others.
Content: A student is writing an opinion paper. Read the draft.

:ibox:I appreciate all four seasons, but fall is my favorite. It is the best time of year. There are many reasons why I enjoy the fall.

F͟i͟r͟s͟t͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟a͟l͟l͟,͟ ͟c͟h͟i͟l͟l͟y͟ ͟f͟a͟l͟l͟ ͟d͟a͟y͟s͟ ͟a͟r͟e͟ ͟a͟ ͟r͟e͟l͟i͟e͟f͟ ͟a͟f͟t͟e͟r͟ ͟a͟ ͟l͟o͟n͟g͟ ͟h͟o͟t͟ ͟s͟u͟m͟m͟e͟r͟. It is neither too hot nor too cold. The weather feels comfortable and pleasant. My mom likes to make delicious, warm soups as it gets cold outside. People tend to do more outdoor activities when the temperature starts to drop.
Which sentence from the draft should be removed because it does NOT support the underlined idea?

A.Choice: It is neither too hot nor too cold.

B.Choice: The weather feels comfortable and pleasant.

C.Choice: My mom likes to make delicious, warm soups as it gets cold outside.

D.Choice: People tend to do more outdoor activities when the temperature starts to drop.

SubTopics: Provide a concluding statement or section relate to the information or explanation presented.
Content: A student wrote a paragraph explaining the results of a science experiment. Read the paragraph.

:ibox:Today our class completed a science experiment. We were trying to find out whether we could stop apple slices from turning brown. Ms. Thompson gave each team of students pieces of an apple that she had cut. We put each piece into a small dish. Then, we poured lemon juice, olive oil, water, vinegar, or saltwater over each piece of apple. One piece was left as a control. That means that we did not add anything to one of the dishes with an apple slice. After everything was ready, we took notes about the appearance of each piece of apple. Throughout the day, we came back to check on our experiment and took more notes on any changes we saw. I noticed that the control was the first piece of apple to turn brown. The piece of apple in the lemon juice had changed the least by the end of the day. Ms. Thompson told us that the acid in the lemon juice is what helped keep the apple from turning brown. All of the liquids slowed the browning of the apple slices at least a little because the liquid can protect the fruit from the air. The air reacts with the fruit, causing it to turn brown.
Which sentence provides the BEST conclusion for the paragraph?

A.Choice: I liked this science experiment more than if we had read something in our science textbook.

B.Choice: We needed to clean up the dishes and the rest of our area after the experiment was finished.

C.Choice: Joey thought the piece of apple in the vinegar turned brown faster than the one in the olive oil.

D.Choice: Now I know that a good way to keep an apple slice looking fresh longer is to dip it in lemon juice.

SubTopics: Use coordinating and subordinating conjunctions.
Content: Read the sentences.
:ibox:People visiting Myrtle Beach may want to think before riding the huge Ferris wheel. It soars about 200 feet above the Atlantic Ocean.
Which conjunction correctly combines the two sentences?

A.Choice: People visiting Myrtle Beach may want to think before riding the huge Ferris wheel since it soars about 200 feet above the Atlantic Ocean.

B.Choice: People visiting Myrtle Beach may want to think before riding the huge Ferris wheel even though it soars about 200 feet above the Atlantic Ocean.

C.Choice: People visiting Myrtle Beach may want to think before riding the huge Ferris wheel as long as it soars about 200 feet above the Atlantic Ocean.

D.Choice: People visiting Myrtle Beach may want to think before riding the huge Ferris wheel whenever it soars about 200 feet above the Atlantic Ocean.
